Definition {#definition .unnumbered}
==========

An *orthonormal set* is a subset $S$ of an inner product space, such
that $\ip{x,y}=\delta_{xy}$ for all $x,y\in S$. Here $\ip{\cdot,\cdot}$
is the inner product, and $\delta$ is the Kronecker delta.

More verbosely, we may say that an orthonormal set is a subset $S$ of an
inner product space such that the following two conditions hold:

1.  If $x,y \in S$ and $x\ne y$, then $x$ is to $y$.

2.  If $x \in S$, then the norm of $x$ is $1$.

Stated this way, the origin of the term is clear: an orthonormal set of
vectors is both orthogonal and normalized.

Notes {#notes .unnumbered}
=====

Note that the empty set is orthonormal, as is a set consisting of a
single vector of unit norm in an inner product space.

The columns (or rows) of a real orthogonal matrix form an orthonormal
set. In fact, this is an example of an orthonormal basis.

Applications {#applications .unnumbered}
============

A standard application is finding an orthonormal basis for a vector
space, such as by Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization. Orthonormal bases are
computationally simple to work with.
